title-group.article-title: Phylogenetic analyses of the subfamily Scarabaeinae (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae) provide new insights into the Mexican Transition Zone theory

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Phylogenetic analyses of the subfamily Scarabaeinae ( Coleoptera : Scarabaeidae ) provide new insights into the Mexican Transition Zone theory

VICTOR MOCTEZUMA 1* , ALEJANDRO ESPINOSA DE LOS MONTEROS 2 & GONZALO HALFFTER 3† 1 Centro Tlaxcala de Biología de la Conducta, Universidad Autónoma de Tlaxcala, km 1.5 Carretera Tlaxcala-Puebla S/N, La Loma Xicohtencatl, Tlaxcala de Xicohténcatl, 90070 Tlaxcala, Mexico.
Ễ abadonjvpm@hotmail.com; https://orcid.org/0000-0002-4532-0302
2 Red de Biología Evolutiva, Instituto de Ecología, A. C., Carretera antigua a Coatepec 351, El Haya, Xalapa, 91073 Veracruz, Mexico.
Ễ alejandro.espinosa@inecol.mx; https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7742-5977
3 Emeritous Researcher, Instituto de Ecología, A. C., Carretera antigua a Coatepec 351, El Haya, Xalapa, 91073 Veracruz, Mexico. https://orcid.org/ 0000-0003-1430-7049
† Deceased
* Corresponding author

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p: Being areas of biotic overlap located between biogeographic regions, transition zones function as natural laboratories. The present study explores the phylogenetic history of the dung beetle subfamily Scarabaeinae , in order to present an evolutionary scenario that allows inference of the biogeographic history of the Mexican Transition Zone (MTZ) and integration of the distributional patterns of its biota. The species sampling included 94 New World taxa (93 species of Scarabaeinae and one species of Aphodiinae ).The phylogenetic relationships of the main clades recovered in our study were supported with PP values ≥ 0.95. Based on the BAYAREALIKE model to reconstruct the ancestral distributional patterns of Scarabaeinae , we inferred a complex scenario with 19 dispersal events, 15 vicariance events, and three extinctions. We suggest that the Ancient Neotropical and Tropical Paleoamerican patterns represent the most likely ancestral distributional patterns for the Scarabaeinae of the MTZ, which probably settle there during the Eocene-Oligocene. The rest of the Scarabaeinae distributional patterns were assembled in subsequent periods. The results suggest that the MTZ had two separate formation stages: a Paleo-MTZ (Eocene-Miocene) and a current MTZ (Pliocene-Anthropocene). We conclude that the evolutionary history as well as the dispersal-vicariance scenario for the Scarabaeinae of the MTZ fits the “out of the tropics” model.

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Key words: biogeography , dung beetles , Nearctic region , Neotropical region , out of the tropics model

sec.title: Introduction
N/A
sec.p: We used sequences of 94 taxa of the subfamily Scarabaeinae ( Table 1 ). Most of the taxa selected are distributed in the MTZ. Thirty-three taxa were collected in the field and sequenced de novo for this study (accession numbers under request). The rest of the taxa were selected according to the availability of database sequences (GenBank).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: ......continued on the next page

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: ......continued on the next page

sec.title: DNA extraction, PCR, and sequencing techniques
sec.p: The PCRs were run in a final reaction volume of 25 µl: 1 µl DNA (20–40 ng), 4 µl 5X Buffer, 2 µl MgCl2 (25 mM), 2.5 µl dNTPs (8 lM), 0.25 µl BSA, 0.8 µl of each primer (10 µM), 0.2 µl Taq polymerase (5 U/ µl) and 13.35 µl ddH2O. PCR cycling conditions were as follows: initial denaturing at 94 °C for 3 min, followed by 30 cycles at 94 °C for 1 min for denaturing, 50 °C for 1 min for annealing, and 70 °C for 2 min for extension, finishing with a final extension step at 72 °C for 5 min. Variations of this protocol were used for problematic samples: the best yield for 16S was obtained with 35 cycles, whereas the optimal annealing for ITS 2 was performed at 53 °C. PCR products were visualized on 1% agarose gels stained with ethidium bromide and purified with the QIAquick kit (QIAGEN). PCR purifications were sequenced abroad by Macrogen Inc. (Seoul, South Korea).

sec.title: Sequence alignment and phylogenetic inference
Divergence time estimation
Ancestral State Reconstruction
Results
sec.p: The length of the alignment obtained with the four loci was 3156 base pairs ( ITS 2 = 736 bp, 16S = 539 bp, COI = 1261 bp and COII = 620 bp). The de novo sequences were deposited in GenBank ( Table 1 , accession numbers under request). The best-fit models of nucleotide substitution were: GTR (nst=6) + Inv (0.699) for ITS 2, TVM (nst=6) + Inv (0.259) + Gamma (0.386) for 16S, GTR (nst=6) + Inv (0.412) + Gamma (0.375) for COI, and TrN (nst=6) + Inv (0.341) + Gamma (0.277) for COII . Phylogenetic relationships of major clades represented in our study are supported with PP values ≥ 0.95 ( Fig. 2 ).

sec.title: Divergence time estimates
sec.p:
It is important to make clear that the temporal scenario recovered here is mainly based on the dates inferred for the nodes of the phylogenetic tree. These nodes represent the splitting events of the lineages and not necessarily the exact time at which the distributional patterns were consolidated. Nonetheless, the dates are the average time value associated with a statistical variance that implies temporal uncertainty. The historical scenario presented here thus should be scrutinized when more accurate methods for estimating time are available. The inferred chronogram ( Fig. 2 ) suggests that the events of diversification that lead to the radiation of the lineages currently distributed at the MTZ occurred between 54 and 18 Myr ago. The tribe Phanaeini began its diversification around 23.4 Myr ago (95% confidence limits 18.4–28.5 Myr). Another important evolutionary event was the radiation of the genus
Onthophagus Latreille, 1802
, which began approximately 26.7 Myr ago (95% confidence limits 22.6–31 Myr). The radiation events of other important genera began almost simultaneously, as was the case of
Copris Geoffroy, 1762
(26.7 Myr; 95% confidence limits 17.4–36.4 Myr),
Uroxys Westwood, 1842
(24.2 Myr; 95% confidence limits 16.6–31.8 Myr) and
Eurysternus Dalman, 1824
(28.7 Myr; 95% confidence limits 21.6–35.1 Myr). The most recent radiation events correspond to
Dichotomius Hope, 1838
(19.8 Myr; 95% confidence limits 11.6–29 Myr),
Canthidium Erichson, 1847
(18.2 Myr; 95% confidence limits 11.2–25.6 Myr) and
Ateuchus Weber, 1801
(15.3 Myr; 95% confidence limits 10.3–21.2 Myr).

sec.title: Reconstruction of ancestral stages and biogeographic scenario
sec.p:
The BAYAREALIKE model suggests a scenario comprising multiple dispersal and diversification events of the Scarabaeinae that promoted the assembly of the distributional patterns in the MTZ. The analysis infers 19 events of dispersal, 15 events of vicariance and 3 extinctions ( Fig. 3 ). The Typical Neotropical distribution scored the greatest diversification and the highest number of dispersal events ( Tables 2–3 ). During the Oligocene-Pleistocene, multiple speciation events were presented for genera such as
Ateuchus ,
Canthon Hoffmannsegg, 1817
,
Canthidium , Dichotomius , Eurysternus ,
Phanaeus MacLeay, 1819
,
Scatimus Erichson, 1847
, and
Uroxys
. The theory of the MTZ considers that the ancestors of those taxa were part of the Typical Neotropical distribution. In particular, the Typical Neotropical distribution of the genus
Phanaeus
yielded to the lineages with Mexican Plateau distribution during the Miocene. The ancestor of the taxa that follow the Mexican Plateau distribution appeared during the Miocene ( i.e. ,
P. yecoraensis Edmonds, 2004
+
P. vindex MacLeay, 1819
+
P. igneus MacLeay, 1819
+
P. furiosus Bates, 1887
+
P. nimrod Harold, 1863
+
P. texensis Edmonds, 1994
+
P. quadridens (Say, 1835))
. At the end of the Miocene, the taxa with a Mexican Plateau distribution diversified and gave origin to the lineage
P. endymion Harold, 1863
+
P. pyrois Bates, 1887
. Also, during the Miocene the Mountain Mesoamerican distribution was integrated by three different speciation events corresponding to the genera
Eurysternus
(
E. magnus Castelnau, 1840
),
Phanaeus
(
P. amethystinus Harold, 1863
+
P. guatemalensis Harold, 1871
) and
Ontherus
(
O. mexicanus Harold, 1868
), and an additional event during the early Pliocene (
A. colossus Moctezuma, Sánchez-Huerta & Halffter, 2018
).

The ancestors of the Paleoamerican genera
Copris
and
Onthophagus
appeared in the MTZ during the Oligocene. In the genus
Copris
, the ancestors of the Mesoamerican Paleoamerican (
C. chimalapensis Mora-Aguilar & Delgado, 2015
) and Mountain Paleoamerican (
C. armatus Harold, 1869
) distributions originated during the Miocene. The Tropical Paleoamerican distribution appeared as an ancestral stage in the genus
Onthophagus
from which the rest of the Paleoamerican distributions originated. In this genus, the Mesoamerican Paleoamerican distribution appeared during the Miocene as a result of a cladogenesis event (
O. cyanellus Bates, 1887
), while the Mountain Paleoamerican distribution arose from two different cladogenesis events (
O. orizabensis Moctezuma, Joaqui & Sánchez-Huerta, 2019
and
O. halffteri Zunino, 1981
) during the same period of time. The Mexican Plateau Paleoamerican distribution was the result of three independent events, two during the Miocene (
O. pennsylvanicus Harold, 1871
+
O. etlaensis Kohlmann, Escobar-Hernández & Arriaga-Jiménez, 2019
;
O. orpheus (Panzer, 1794)
+
O. anthracinus Harold, 1873
+
O. hecate (Panzer, 1794))
and one during the Plio-Pleistocene (
O. nitidior Bates, 1887
).

sec.title: Discussion
Divergence times
Distributional patterns
Mountain Mesoamerican distributional pattern
Mexican Plateau distributional pattern
Typical Neotropical distributional pattern
sec.p:
According to our temporal scenario, two diversification events during the Plio-Pleistocene within the genus
Eurysternus
fit the Typical Neotropical pattern (
E. mexicanus Harold, 1869
+
E. obliteratus Génier, 2009
; and
E. foedus Guérin-Méneville, 1830
+
E. velutinus Bates, 1887
). In addition, the speciation events that resulted in
A. chrysopygus Bates, 1887
,
C. pluto (Harold, 1863)
,
C. corythus (Harold, 1863)
,
P. demon Castelnau, 1840
, and
D. amplicollis Harold, 1869
also support the Plio-Pleistocene diversification of the Typical Neotropical pattern (
,
;
). Finally,
,
) have suggested that the roller dung beetle
Canthon cyanellus LeConte, 1859
is a complex of cryptic species that probably diversified during the Pleistocene, representing another lineage that adequately describes this Typical Neotropical distributional pattern.

Phanaeus endymion
+
P. pyrois
are species endemic to the tropical rainforests at the MTZ (Moctezuma & Halffter, 2021), and were subject to a Pleistocene speciation event consistent with the Typical Neotropical distributional pattern. It would be expected that the hypothetical ancestors of Typical Neotropical lineages were Neotropical elements of South American origin (
,
;
). Our results, however, suggest that
P. endymion
+
P. pyrois
originated from an ancestor that followed the Mexican Plateau distributional pattern. This agrees with the phylogenetic hypothesis presented by
, where
P. endymion
and related species were nested within a clade that includes species that inhabit the Mexican Plateau. As a consequence, we propose herein that the Typical Neotropical pattern not only is integrated by Scarabaeinae lineages with ancestors that dispersed from South America during the Plio-Pleistocene, but some lineages originated from dispersal events of ancestors that previously inhabited the Mexican Plateau.

sec.title: The Oligocene-Miocene Neotropical diversification and a new distributional pattern
sec.p:
Some genera that were classified in previous studies as Typical Neotropical probably dispersed towards the MTZ during the Oligocene (e.g.,
Canthon
,
Deltochilum
,
Eurysternus
,
Scatimus
and
Uroxys
). The dispersal of this group of taxa might be explained by the presence of the proto-Antilles in the Caribbean Sea during the Eocene-Oligocene that allowed the exchange of fauna between North and South America (
;
). Other Neotropical taxa included in our study (
Ateuchus , Canthidium ,
Coprophanaeus Olsoufieff, 1924
,
Dichotomius , Phanaeus
and
Sulcophanaeus Olsoufieff, 1924
) probably dispersed to the MTZ and diversified during the Miocene. The Panama Seaway Closure could have favored the dispersal of these genera. Recent studies suggest that this event started to consolidate during the mid-Miocene, facilitating the dispersal of different groups of organisms in periods prior to the GABI (
;
,
). Even if the Panamanian Land Bridge formed around 3 Myr ago (
), the Neotropical dung beetles might have dispersed to the MTZ from northern South America by an “island hopper” process using the Central American Volcanic Arc islands formed during the Oligocene-Miocene.
suggest that the faunal interchange between South and Central America started around 30 Myr ago, and this interchange intensified at least 20 Myr ago for the Neotropical spider genus
Micrathena Sundevall, 1833
. Our results are consistent with those presented by
, who suggested that some Neotropical Deltochilini lineages from the MTZ, such as
C. indigaceus LeConte, 1866
and
Pseudocanthon perplexus (LeConte, 1847)
, appeared during the Miocene-Pliocene as a result of different cladogenetic and dispersal events.

The Neotropical elements that dispersed to the MTZ during the Miocene-Oligocene do not fit with the Typical Neotropical distributional pattern as currently defined. In order to separate these Neotropical elements that represent the oldest dispersal and diversification events in the MTZ, we propose a new distributional pattern: the Ancient Neotropical. This distributional pattern includes extant species and lineages ( i.e. ,
C. pseudopuncticolle
+
C. ardens
+
C. guanacaste
,
D. satanas
+
D. yucatanus
+
D. colonicus
,
E. hamaticollis
+
E. caribaeus
+
E. plebejus
+
E. angustulus
), which diversified during the Miocene, and the hypothetical Neotropical ancestors that appeared during the Oligocene-Miocene. In this regard, the Ancient Neotropical represents the ancestral distributional pattern of South American origin in the MTZ, which gave rise to the rest of the Neotropical distributional patterns ( i.e. , Mexican Plateau, Mountain Mesoamerican, Baja Californian, and Typical Neotropical).

Some examples of the close phylogenetic relationship between the Neotropical and African Scarabaeinae are represented by
Eurysternus
(sister group of the clade
Epactoides Olsoufieff, 1947
+
Ochicanthon
Vaz-de-Mello, 2003;
),
Streblopus Van Lansberge, 1874
(closely related to
Circellium Latreille, 1825
and Scarabaeini ; Cupello et al . 2020),
Gromphas Brullé, 1838
(whose phylogenetic placement within Phanaeini or Onitini is disputed;
;
), and Deltochilini (which were placed as the sister group of a clade that contains the tribes Eurysternini, Gymnopleurini, Oniticellini, Onitini, Onthophagini and Sisyphini;
). The phylogenetic relationships and putative ancestry of the Neotropical genera
Uroxys Westwood, 1842
and
Bdelyropsis Pereira, Vulcano & Martínez, 1960
represent a particularly enigmatic case.
suggested that both are nested within the Australasian endemic genera. Also,
indicated that
Uroxys
and
Bdelyropsis
are sister to other Neotropical taxa; while
proposed that those genera conform the sister group of the African
Pedaria Laporte, 1832
and the Australian
Boletoscapter Matthews, 1974
.

Further studies are needed to understand if the morphological affinities of
Uroxys
and
Bdelyropsis
with different New World genera (
) are a consequence of convergent evolution. The phylogenetic relationships proposed by
indicate an Australasian ancestry for both genera; therefore, they would not be consistent with the Ancient Neotropical pattern as proposed herein. Furthermore,
suggested a likely Gondwanan origin for these Neotropical genera, which is not consistent with our results. As an alternative explanation, the sister relationship of
Uroxys
,
Bdelyropsis
,
Pedaria
, and
Boletoscapter
recovered by
may be the result of a transoceanic dispersal of closely related African ancestors that gave rise to the Neotropical and Australian genera, which make plausible our hypothesis of the Ancient Neotropical distributional pattern with an Afrotropical ancestry.

sec.title: Paleoamerican distributional pattern
The paleogeographic scenario and formation of the MTZ
Conclusions
sec.p: We address the theory of the MTZ and its distributional patterns with the phylogenetic reconstruction of a group of dung beetles, the subfamily Scarabaeinae . This phylogenetic hypothesis is the most complete to date for the MTZ Scarabaeinae . The Ancient Neotropical and Tropical Paleoamerican represented the ancestral distributional patters in our phylogenetic hypothesis. As a consequence, we suggest that the Scarabaeinae of the MTZ diversified in tropical environments from a very early stage of their evolutionary history (Eocene-Oligocene). The Scarabaeinae subsequently dispersed towards extratropical environments during the Miocene in which the greatest process of adaptive radiation took place. This period saw the rise of the rest of the distribution patterns of the MTZ (Mountain Paleoamerican, Mountain Mesoamerican, Mesoamerican Paleoamerican, Mexican Plateau and Mexican Plateau Paleoamerican).

sec.title: Acknowledgments
sec.p: We thank Keith MacMillan for English language translation and edition. To Janeth Nolasco-Soto (INECOL) for logistic and technical support. To Fernando Vaz-de-Mello (UFMT) and Mario Favila (INECOL) for their valuable comments on a preliminary version of this manuscript. The commentaries by Juan J. Morrone and an anonymous reviewer helped improve this manuscript. José Luis Sánchez-Huerta (Mexico) was instrumental for fieldwork. Fieldwork would have not been possible without the support and friendship of the inhabitants of Los Chimalapas region, Oaxaca, Mexico; particularly those of the communities of Benito Juárez, San Antonio, San Francisco La Paz, San Miguel Chimalapa and Santa María Chimalapa. Maderas del Pueblo del Sureste, A. C. provided logistic support for fieldwork. We sincerely thank the General Direction of the Instituto de Ecología, A.C. (No. 20035/30916), the Fondo Sectorial de Investigación para la Educación SEP-CONAHCYT-Mexico (No. 257039), and the Organization for Tropical Studies (Hovore-Horn Fellowship No. 3116) for funding this research. CONAHCYT awarded grants for graduate studies, research assistant activities and postdoctoral fellowship to Victor Moctezuma (CVU 486765). Unfortunately, Professor Gonzalo Halffter passed away before the final version of this work was prepared.
